channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Perl Developer and Business Owner? Remote Perl role in UK & EU
item.description: Our clients run a job search engine that has grown from two friends with an idea to a site that receives more than 10 million visits per month. They're looking for a Perl pro with at least three years of experience with high-volume and high-traffic apps and sites, a solid understanding of Object-Oriented Perl (perks if that knowledge includes Moose), SQL/MySQL and DBIx::Class.

item.title: C, C++, and Perl Software Engineers, Let’s Keep the Internet Safe. Remote UK Perl Role
item.description: A leading digital safeguarding solutions provider is looking for a software engineer experienced in C, C++, or Perl. You’ll have strong Linux knowledge and a methodical approach to problem solving that you use to investigate, replicate, and address customer issues. Your keen understanding of firewalls, proxies, Iptables, Squid, VPNs/IPSec and HTTP(S) will be key to your success at this company.

item.title: Senior Perl Developer with Cross-Trained Chops. UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: Sure, you’ve got Perl chops for days, but that’s not all you can do — and that’s why our client wants to meet you. They’re looking for senior Perl developers, Node engineers, and those with mighty Python and SQL skills to lead their team. Cross-trained team members are their sweet spot, and whether you’re cross-trained yourself or are open to the possibility, this may be your perfect role.

item.title: Adventure! Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: Clever folks know that if you’re lucky, you can earn a living and have an adventure at the same time. Enter our international client: online trading is their game, and they’re looking for Perl folks with passion, drive, and an appreciation for new experiences.

item.title: Day 23: CI using timescaledb a PostgreSQL based time series database
item.description: Though this is a Ruby project, it was very interesting (and complex) setting up the Continuous Integration.

item.title: Day 25: CI for Data::Alias in Perl - including threaded perl
item.description: A simple GitHub Action configuration with some twist

item.title: Billions of unnecessary files in GitHub
item.description: People seem to ignore the .gitignore file.

item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.description: Despite being holiday season, we still got creative post, thanks for your contributions.

item.description: Interesting bunch of Perl and Python creations. Keep it up great work.

item.description: Roger's collection always has the surprising element, you don't want to miss. Highly recommended.

item.description: Nice and easy task analysis. There is always something to learn.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 196
item.description: Master of Perl one-liner is at it again. You don't want to miss the fun.

item.title: Merry Christmas!
item.description: Along with Raku, we get SQL version too every week. Nice treat for all of us, thanks.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 196: Pattern 132 and Range List
item.description: Being one of the regular contributors, Laurent never misses the opportunity to entertain us every week.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 196
item.description: James is known for compact and powerful solution. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 196
item.description: Thanks for getting blog post ready at the airport. I salute your dedication.

item.title: PWC196 - Range List
item.description: Lucky twice this week, no questions asked. Thank you for sharing knowledge.

item.title: PWC196 - Pattern 132
item.description: No new questions, that is win for me. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Insert Clever Title Here
item.description: Welcome back to blogging after a short break. The title is really unique. Well done.

item.title: Range Rover, Over Clover
item.description: Task analysis by Colin is the highlight of the blog post for me. Keep it up great work.

item.title: 132 Lists
item.description: Nice trick to deal with data type, thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge Advent Calendar 2022
item.description: Finally we now have a complete Advent Calendar 2022. Enjoy !!!

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 196
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Pattern 132" and "Range List" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 197
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Move Zero" and "Wiggle Sort". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: AoC 2022/15 - Diamonds are squares in disguise
How to find files in a directory in Perl?
item.description: Nice and easy solution.

item.description: Saif is back in action after a long break with yet another engaging topic.

item.title: Linux::NFTables
item.description: Perl interface to libnftables.

item.title: Writing a CPAN module that talks to ChatGPT
item.description: ChatGPT is the hot topic now a days and Dave shared his view on the same.

item.title: Catalyst Framework
item.description: For any of the Catalyst programmers out there interested in seeing the framework move forward, here's a PR that changes action chaining so that you can call the next action from within the action code, optionally passing and recieving arguments.

item.title: First round of feature 'class'
item.description: Paul "LeoNerd" Evans has created the first pull request for Corinna, the modern OOP system for Perl. Merry Christmas!

item.title: #596 - New Year Resolution
item.description:
Hi there,

With the end of Advent Calendar celebration, another celebration kicks in i.e. Christmas/Boxing Day. Although I don't celebrate, being a Muslim, but I do enjoy the break from the routine work.

This edition of the weekly newsletter is my 120th edition. I hope you enjoy reading the newsletter as much as I do getting ready for you.

Do you have any new year resolutions?

I used to but then last year I stopped it.

Why?

Well couple of projects closed to my heart didn't get started and that made me very pessimistic. I feel so bad that I don't even talk about it. I hope new year will bring positive change.

Still, I don't feel like setting new year resolutions. Could it be, I am getting old to keep up with fast pace dev life? Having said, the dev inside me still alive but just needs some push. Fortunately I have so many people around me that always gives me much needed positive energy.

Let's talk about some positivity now. Well for me, it was the Perl Advent Calendar 2022, thanks to Olaf Alders and team. I wanted to be part of it but then missed the train unfortunately. Never mind, there is always next time. Having said, I did manage to get the post up but was too late to make it. Fortunately my contribution to Raku Advent Calendar 2022 did work out nicely like Raku and I.

Enjoy rest of the holidays and stay safe.
item.dc:subject: editorial
